awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cloud Radiative Impact on the Surface Energy Budget of the Antarctic Peninsula
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The Western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP; AP) has been warming faster than the global average since the mid-1960s. Concurrent mobilization of ice shelves has been associated with glacial discharge into the ocean, with important implications for global sea level rise. This work will enhance our understanding of the contributions of clouds, water vapor and surface radiation to warming over the WAP. Processes governing phase partitioning and amounts of supercooled liquid water are crucial for understanding surface melt, and will be explored. In addition, the role of clouds and moisture during foehn and atmospheric river (AR) events, will be characterized. Clouds and atmospheric water vapor have strong radiative signals that vary seasonally and with cloud properties. This work will lead to a better understanding of how clouds are impacting surface melt on the AP in the changing climate. In addition, the proposed work will include several undergraduate research projects. Finally, broader impacts include public outreach through participation in GeoWeek at Ohio State University and Polar Science Weekend at the Pacific Science Center in Seattle, WA.  It is crucial to human welfare to understand mechanisms responsible for the rapid pace of Antarctic ice loss. This work will lead to a better understanding of how clouds are impacting surface melt on the WAP in the changing climate. 


The project  will use surface- and satellite-based measurements to characterize clouds and humidity. The project maximizes value by using a variety of previous, ongoing, and planned measurements made by an international group of collaborators, along with measurements and model (AMPS, Polar-WRF) results. These will be used to quantify clouds, water vapor, and radiation and their effects on the surface energy balance at three strategically-located stations: Rothera (upwind of the WAP), Marambio (downwind of the WAP) and Escudero (north of the WAP), in order to provide a detailed characterization of cloud radiative and precipitation-formation properties and their role in surface warming and melt events. These mechanisms lead to the following hypotheses: 1) Through their effect on the surface energy balance, clouds play an important role in surface warming on the AP; this role is seasonally varying and sensitive to cloud thermodynamic phase, 2) Radiative heating during foehn events is an important contributor to warming at the northern AP, and 3) The radiative effects of clouds and water vapor have strong influences on heating before and during AR events, with significant differences on the two sides of the WAP.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Antarctic ice shelves provide a buttressing effect on Antarctic glaciers, blocking them from flowing into the sea. However, surface warming can lead to the collapse of ice shelves, accelerating the flow of glaciers and raising sea level. Two phenomena that enhance surface warming on the Antarctic Peninsula are foehn and atmospheric rivers. Foehn are warm, dry downslope winds caused by air passing over the mountains that run the length of the Peninsula. Atmospheric rivers are long corridors of moisture that bring heat and precipitation to the Antarctic. Clouds also play a critical but complex role in surface warming, particularly during atmospheric rivers, causing cooling by reflecting sunlight back to space, and warming by trapping infrared light. 

This work was motivated by the need to better understand how clouds, atmospheric rivers, and foehn impact warming over the Antarctic Peninsula and Southern Ocean. Our goals were to characterize clouds at a research station in the Southern Ocean, near the northern end of the Antarctic Peninsula, the Chilean Research Station Escudero, and to investigate mechanisms of warming during atmospheric river and foehn events, particularly those involving clouds. 

We found that for two combined atmospheric river and foehn events that impacted the northeastern Antarctic Peninsula, occurring in December 2018 and February 2022, the main warming mechanism during the nighttime was transfer of heat from the air to the ice surface (called sensible heat flux), while the main mechanism during the daytime was intense sunlight. The sunlight was able to reach the surface because the foehn dried the air so that there were fewer clouds to block the sun. However, complicating the picture, the atmospheric river was able to flow through gaps in the Antarctic Peninsula mountain range, allowing clouds to form on the other side, which then blocked some of the sunlight.

We characterized clouds over King George Island, located in the Southern Ocean just north of the Antarctic Peninsula, using measurements made at the Chilean research station Professor Julio Escudero during 2017-2023. In addition to cloud height, we measured the amount of sunlight and infrared radiation making it to the surface. We found that clouds are present 96% of the time, and that they are typically very low. Temperatures at the cloud bases tend to be just below freezing. Because the air is so clean, most of the clouds contain liquid even at these supercooled temperatures. Overall, we found that clouds cause a cooling effect in summer and a warming effect during fall, winter, and spring. We also found that the widely-used ERA5 dataset, produced by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts, underestimates the time span when clouds cause an overall warming by about 2 and a half weeks.

Our work was shared with the scientific community through numerous publications and presentations. In addition, we participated in the Year of Polar Prediction in the Southern Hemisphere (YOPP-SH), an international effort to improve weather forecasting in the Antarctic region. We also supported STEM education through mentoring students and working with instructors to create and teach educational materials that improve polar literacy, through an NSF-funded project called Polar STEAM. This project also supported an undergraduate intern via UCSD GEOPaths Program. Filip Oliver from MiraCosta College has been working on a 6-month research project named “Unveiling Extreme Weather and Surface Melting over the Antarctic Peninsula Triggered by Atmospheric Rivers”. Filip presented a poster on this project at the 2024 CW3E Annual Meeting.
